title.rendered: What is JavaScript?

content.rendered: JavaScript is a client-side as well as server side scripting language that can be inserted into HTML pages and is understood by web browsers. JavaScript is also an Object based Programming language

excerpt.rendered: JavaScript is a client-side as well as server side scripting language that can be inserted into HTML pages and is understood by web browsers. JavaScript is also an Object based Programming language

title.rendered: Enumerate the differences between Java and JavaScript?

content.rendered: Java is a complete programming language. In contrast, JavaScript is a coded program that can be introduced to HTML pages. These two languages are not at all inter-dependent and are designed for the different intent. Java is an object – oriented programming (OOPS) or structured programming language like C++ or C whereas JavaScript is a client-side scripting language.

excerpt.rendered: Java is a complete programming language. In contrast, JavaScript is a coded program that can be introduced to HTML pages. These two languages are not at all inter-dependent and are designed for the different intent. Java is an object – oriented programming (OOPS) or structured programming language like C++ or C whereas JavaScript is a […]

title.rendered: What are JavaScript Data Types?

content.rendered:
Following are the JavaScript Data types:

  • Number
  • String
  • Boolean
  • Object
  • Undefined

excerpt.rendered: Following are the JavaScript Data types: Number String Boolean Object Undefined

title.rendered: Between JavaScript and an ASP script, which is faster?

content.rendered: JavaScript is faster. JavaScript is a client-side language and thus it does not need the assistance of the web server to execute. On the other hand, ASP is a server-side language and hence is always slower than JavaScript. Javascript now is also a server side language (nodejs).

excerpt.rendered: JavaScript is faster. JavaScript is a client-side language and thus it does not need the assistance of the web server to execute. On the other hand, ASP is a server-side language and hence is always slower than JavaScript. Javascript now is also a server side language (nodejs).

title.rendered: Is it possible to break JavaScript Code into several lines?

content.rendered:
Breaking within a string statement can be done by the use of a backslash, ‘\’, at the end of the first line

Example:

document.write("This is \a program");

And if you change to a new line when not within a string statement, then javaScript ignores break in line.

Example:

var x=1, y=2,
z=
x+y;

The above code is perfectly fine, though not advisable as it hampers debugging.

excerpt.rendered: Breaking within a string statement can be done by the use of a backslash, ‘\’, at the end of the first line Example: And if you change to a new line when not within a string statement, then javaScript ignores break in line. Example: The above code is perfectly fine, though not advisable as it […]

title.rendered: What are undeclared and undefined variables?

content.rendered:
Undeclared variables are those that do not exist in a program and are not declared. If the program tries to read the value of an undeclared variable, then a runtime error is encountered.

Undefined variables are those that are declared in the program but have not been given any value. If the program tries to read the value of an undefined variable, an undefined value is returned.

excerpt.rendered: Undeclared variables are those that do not exist in a program and are not declared. If the program tries to read the value of an undeclared variable, then a runtime error is encountered. Undefined variables are those that are declared in the program but have not been given any value. If the program tries to […]

title.rendered: Write the code for adding new elements dynamically?

content.rendered:
<html> 
<head> 
<title>t1</title> 
<script type="text/javascript"> 
	function addNode() { var newP = document.createElement("p"); 
	var textNode = document.createTextNode(" This is a new text node"); 
	newP.appendChild(textNode); document.getElementById("firstP").appendChild(newP); } 
</script> </head> 
<body> <p id="firstP">firstP<p> </body> 
</html>

title.rendered: What are global variables? How are these variable declared and what are the problems associated with using them?

content.rendered:
Global variables are those that are available throughout the length of the code, that is, these have no scope. The var keyword is used to declare a local variable or object. If the var keyword is omitted, a global variable is declared.

Example:

// Declare a global globalVariable = "Test";

The problems that are faced by using global variables are the clash of variable names of local and global scope. Also, it is difficult to debug and test the code that relies on global variables.

excerpt.rendered: Global variables are those that are available throughout the length of the code, that is, these have no scope. The var keyword is used to declare a local variable or object. If the var keyword is omitted, a global variable is declared. Example: The problems that are faced by using global variables are the clash […]

title.rendered: Explain the working of timers in JavaScript? Also elucidate the drawbacks of using the timer, if any?

content.rendered:
Timers are used to execute a piece of code at a set time or also to repeat the code in a given interval of time. This is done by using the functions setTimeout, setInterval and clearInterval.

The setTimeout(function, delay) function is used to start a timer that calls a particular function after the mentioned delay. The setInterval(function, delay) function is used to repeatedly execute the given function in the mentioned delay and only halts when cancelled. The clearInterval(id) function instructs the timer to stop.

Timers are operated within a single thread, and thus events might queue up, waiting to be executed.

excerpt.rendered: Timers are used to execute a piece of code at a set time or also to repeat the code in a given interval of time. This is done by using the functions setTimeout, setInterval and clearInterval. The setTimeout(function, delay) function is used to start a timer that calls a particular function after the mentioned delay. The setInterval(function, delay) function is used to […]

title.rendered: What is the difference between ViewState and SessionState?

content.rendered:
‘ViewState’ is specific to a page in a session.

‘SessionState’ is specific to user specific data that can be accessed across all pages in the web application.

excerpt.rendered: ‘ViewState’ is specific to a page in a session. ‘SessionState’ is specific to user specific data that can be accessed across all pages in the web application.

title.rendered: Explain how can you submit a form using JavaScript?

content.rendered:
To submit a form using JavaScript use document.form[0].submit();

document.form[0].submit();

excerpt.rendered: To submit a form using JavaScript use document.form[0].submit();

title.rendered: How can the style/class of an element be changed?

content.rendered:
It can be done in the following way:

or

title.rendered: What is called Variable typing in Javascript?

content.rendered:
Variable typing is used to assign a number to a variable and the same variable can be assigned to a string.

Example

i = 10;
i = "string";

This is called variable typing.

excerpt.rendered: Variable typing is used to assign a number to a variable and the same variable can be assigned to a string. Example This is called variable typing.

title.rendered: How can you convert the string of any base to integer in JavaScript?

content.rendered:
The parseInt() function is used to convert numbers between different bases. parseInt() takes the string to be converted as its first parameter, and the second parameter is the base of the given string.

In order to convert 4F (of base 16) to integer, the code used will be –

parseInt ("4F", 16);

content.rendered:
The delete keyword is used to delete the property as well as its value.

Example

delete student.age;

content.rendered:
Undefined value means the

  • Variable used in the code doesn’t exist
  • Variable is not assigned to any value
  • Property doesn’t exist

title.rendered: What are escape characters?

content.rendered:
Escape characters (Backslash) is used when working with special characters like single quotes, double quotes, apostrophes and ampersands. Place backslash before the characters to make it display.

Example:

document.write "I m a "good" boy"
document.write "I m a \"good\" boy"

title.rendered: What are JavaScript Cookies?

content.rendered: Cookies are the small test files stored in a computer and it gets created when the user visits the websites to store information that they need. Example could be User Name details and shopping cart information from the previous visits.

excerpt.rendered: Cookies are the small test files stored in a computer and it gets created when the user visits the websites to store information that they need. Example could be User Name details and shopping cart information from the previous visits.

title.rendered: Explain what is pop()method in JavaScript?

content.rendered:
The pop() method is similar as the shift() method but the difference is that the Shift method works at the start of the array. Also the pop() method take the last element off of the given array and returns it. The array on which is called is then altered.

Example:

var cloths = ["Shirt", "Pant", "TShirt"];
cloths.pop();

//Now cloth becomes Shirt,Pant

excerpt.rendered: The pop() method is similar as the shift() method but the difference is that the Shift method works at the start of the array. Also the pop() method take the last element off of the given array and returns it. The array on which is called is then altered. Example: //Now cloth becomes Shirt,Pant

title.rendered: Mention what is the disadvantage of using innerHTML in JavaScript?

content.rendered:
If you use innerHTML in JavaScript the disadvantage is

  • Content is replaced everywhere
  • We cannot use like “appending to innerHTML”
  • Even if you use +=like “innerHTML = innerHTML + ‘html'” still the old content is replaced by html
  • The entire innerHTML content is re-parsed and build into elements, therefore its much slower
  • The innerHTML does not provide validation and therefore we can potentially insert valid and broken HTML in the document and break it

excerpt.rendered: If you use innerHTML in JavaScript the disadvantage is Content is replaced everywhere We cannot use like “appending to innerHTML” Even if you use +=like “innerHTML = innerHTML + ‘html’” still the old content is replaced by html The entire innerHTML content is re-parsed and build into elements, therefore its much slower The innerHTML does […]

title.rendered: Which keywords are used to handle exceptions?

content.rendered:
Try… Catch—finally is used to handle exceptions in the JavaScript

Try{
	Code
}
Catch(exp){
	Code to throw an exception
}
Finally{
	Code runs either it finishes successfully or after catch
}

excerpt.rendered: Try… Catch—finally is used to handle exceptions in the JavaScript

title.rendered: What are the different types of errors in JavaScript?

content.rendered:
There are three types of errors:

  • Load time errors: Errors which come up when loading a web page like improper syntax errors are known as Load time errors and it generates the errors dynamically.
  • Run time errors: Errors that come due to misuse of the command inside the HTML language.
  • Logical Errors: These are the errors that occur due to the bad logic performed on a function which is having different operation.

excerpt.rendered: There are three types of errors: Load time errors: Errors which come up when loading a web page like improper syntax errors are known as Load time errors and it generates the errors dynamically. Run time errors: Errors that come due to misuse of the command inside the HTML language. Logical Errors: These are the […]

title.rendered: What is the use of Push method in JavaScript?

content.rendered: The push method is used to add or append one or more elements to the end of an Array. Using this method, we can append multiple elements by passing multiple arguments

excerpt.rendered: The push method is used to add or append one or more elements to the end of an Array. Using this method, we can append multiple elements by passing multiple arguments

title.rendered: What is unshift method in JavaScript?

content.rendered: Unshift method is like push method which works at the beginning of the array. This method is used to prepend one or more elements to the beginning of the array.

excerpt.rendered: Unshift method is like push method which works at the beginning of the array. This method is used to prepend one or more elements to the beginning of the array.

title.rendered: How are object properties assigned?

content.rendered:
Properties are assigned to objects in the following way –

obj["class"] = 12;

or

obj.class = 12;

excerpt.rendered: Properties are assigned to objects in the following way – or

title.rendered: What is the ‘Strict’ mode in JavaScript and how can it be enabled?

content.rendered:
Strict Mode adds certain compulsions to JavaScript. Under the strict mode, JavaScript shows errors for a piece of codes, which did not show an error before, but might be problematic and potentially unsafe. Strict mode also solves some mistakes that hamper the JavaScript engines to work efficiently.

Strict mode can be enabled by adding the string literal “use strict” above the file. This can be illustrated by the given example:

function myfunction() {
    "use strict";
    var v = "This is a strict mode function";
}

excerpt.rendered: Strict Mode adds certain compulsions to JavaScript. Under the strict mode, JavaScript shows errors for a piece of codes, which did not show an error before, but might be problematic and potentially unsafe. Strict mode also solves some mistakes that hamper the JavaScript engines to work efficiently. Strict mode can be enabled by adding the […]

title.rendered: What is the way to get the status of a CheckBox?

content.rendered:
The status can be acquired as follows –

alert(document.getElementById(‘checkbox1’).checked);

If the CheckBox will be checked, this alert will return TRUE.

excerpt.rendered: The status can be acquired as follows – alert(document.getElementById(‘checkbox1’).checked); If the CheckBox will be checked, this alert will return TRUE.

title.rendered: Explain window.onload and onDocumentReady?

content.rendered:
The onload function is not run until all the information on the page is loaded. This leads to a substantial delay before any code is executed.

onDocumentReady loads the code just after the DOM is loaded. This allows early manipulation of the code.

excerpt.rendered: The onload function is not run until all the information on the page is loaded. This leads to a substantial delay before any code is executed. onDocumentReady loads the code just after the DOM is loaded. This allows early manipulation of the code.

title.rendered: How will you explain closures in JavaScript? When are they used?

content.rendered:
Closure is a locally declared variable related to a function which stays in memory when the function has returned.

For example:

function greet(message) {

    console.log(message);

}

function greeter(name, age) {

    return name + " says howdy!! He is " + age + " years old";

}

// Generate the message

var message = greeter("James", 23);

// Pass it explicitly to greet

greet(message);

This function can be better represented by using closures

function greeter(name, age) {

    var message = name + " says howdy!! He is " + age + " years old";

    return function greet() {

        console.log(message);

    };

}

// Generate the closure

var JamesGreeter = greeter("James", 23);

// Use the closure

JamesGreeter();

excerpt.rendered: Closure is a locally declared variable related to a function which stays in memory when the function has returned. For example:

title.rendered: How can a value be appended to an array?

content.rendered:
A value can be appended to an array in the given manner –

arr[arr.length] = value;

excerpt.rendered: A value can be appended to an array in the given manner – arr[arr.length] = value;

title.rendered: Explain the for-in loop?

content.rendered:
The for-in loop is used to loop through the properties of an object.

The syntax for the for-in loop is –

for (variable name in object){
	statement or block to execute
}

In each repetition, one property from the object is associated to the variable name, and the loop is continued till all the properties of the object are depleted.

excerpt.rendered: The for-in loop is used to loop through the properties of an object. The syntax for the for-in loop is – In each repetition, one property from the object is associated to the variable name, and the loop is continued till all the properties of the object are depleted.
